newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korean firms get tax breaks in Russian zone.
newsitem.headline: S.Korean firms get tax breaks in Russian zone.

text.p: Russia agreed on Tuesday to tariff and profit tax exemptions for South Korean companies operating in a proposed Russian industrial complex, South Korea's Finance and Economy Ministry said.

South Korea and Russia agreed in 1992 to invest between $150 million and $160 million to build the Nakhodka industrial complex in Maritime Province in the Russian Far East. But the project has been delayed over the issue of tariff and tax benefits.
Tuesday's agreement was concluded during the first round of meetings of the South Korea-Russia Joint Committee on Economic, Scientific and Technological Cooperation held in Seoul.
South Korea's Deputy Prime Minister Kang Kyong-shik and his Russian counterpart Oleg Sysuyev headed the meeting, a ministry statement said.

The two nations also reaffirmed an agreement reached in 1995 that Russia would repay $391 million as part payment for an outstanding loan and interest payments in the form of commodities and helicopters by 1998.
The repayment is part of redemption of a $1.47 billion loan that South Korea had extended in 1991 to the former Soviet Union and interest.
